Most imports from all sources are subject to a temporary import charge of 10 per cent of the landed value. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to residents of other Sterling Area countries may be made freely. Payments to residents of countries outside the Sterling Area require exchange control authorization, which (except for payments to residents of Rhodesia)10 is granted free ly, subject to the presentation of supporting evidence. The completion of an exchange control form is required for payments exceeding £250. Authorized banks are permitted to approve applications for transfers on account of many categories of current invisibles without any limitation, and for other categories up to established limits. Applications for payments in excess of these limits or for purposes for which no delegation of authority has been granted are approved by the Bank of England, provided that no unauthorized capital outflow is involved. Authorized banks may dispatch sterling banknotes to nonresidents except residents of Rhodesia against payment in sterling f rom an External Account or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian pounds. An allowance of up to £250 a person a year in foreign exchange other than Rhodesian pounds may be made available to residents without formality by banks and authorized travel agents for personal travel outside the Sterling Area except to Rhodesia; they may grant further amounts not exceeding £250 a trip subject to completion of a currency declaration by the traveler. For travel for business or pro- fessional reasons, an allowance of up to £250 a trip may similarly be made available without formality by banks and authorized travel agents; in excess of that amount they may issue, upon completion of a currency declaration by the traveler, an allowance of £20 a day, up to a maximum of £1,500 for any one jou rney. Applications for larger amounts or for more than £250 within a period of a month must be referred to the Bank of England, wh ich approves them provided that it is satisfied that the exchange is required for genuine travel purposes. Special regulations apply to travel to Rhodesia. All travel exchange purchased must be recorded in the traveler's passport. In addition, travelers may take with them up to £25 in sterling banknotes, which 10 For security reasons, virtually all current payments to Rhodesia are pro- hibited, except when these result from permitted trade in goods. 579 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM may be exchanged abroad for foreign currency for travel expenditure only; but those traveling direct to the Irish Republic or the Channel Islands may take out any amount. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia and certain exports, mostly of a strategic character, to any other destination require export licenses. All other exports are free of license. Except for exports to Rhodesia, exchange control procedure is waived for exports not exceeding £2,000 f.o.b., other than gifts in kind, for which the upper limit is £100 f.o.b. Exporters to countries outside the Sterling Area other than Rhodesia must obtain payment within six months of shipment, unless special permission has been granted to collect at a later date. Exchange receipts must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Permitted exports to Rhodesia must be paid for in a specified currency (see footnote 3) prior to shipment. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts in specified currencies (see footnote 3) on account of invisibles must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Recipients of foreign exchange may, however, be permitted to retain their exchange in controlled accounts if it is needed for operating purposes. Also, residents are permitted to retain, for use during their next trip abroad, the unused portion of any previous travel exchange allocation, for a period of three months after the exchange was originally obtained. British and foreign banknotes may be brought into the United Kingdom freely. Capital Residents of the United Kingdom who receive the currency of a country outside the Sterling Area other than Rhodesian pounds from certain capital account sources (mainly the sale or redemption of foreign currency securities and the sale or liquidation of direct invest- ments situated outside the Sterling Area) may, in certain circumstances and with permission, use the exchange (which is regarded as invest- ment currency or security dollars once permission has been given) for the purchase abroad of marketable foreign currency securities or sell the exchange for sterling to other residents to be used for the same purpose. If permission is not forthcoming and the foreign exchange is one of the specified currencies (see footnote 3 ), it must be offered for sale at the rates ruling in the official market to an authorized bank in the United Kingdom. If permission is granted, however, the equivalent in specified currency of 25 per cent of the proceeds must 580 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM be sold to an authorized bank for sterling at the official market rate of exchange.11 Applications to have regarded as investment currency any foreign currency belonging to residents of the United Kingdom who are "exempted foreign nationals" are normally considered only in respect of assets held at the time of designation as resident of the United Kingdom by persons so designated prior to July 29, 1965, or of securities acquired through the investment currency market. Proceeds of a capital nature in currencies other than specified currencies are not subject to surrender; however, they may be disposed of only with permission, which may be obtained for the use of such funds by the recipient for investments and for other payments outside the Sterling Area. Residents of the United Kingdom may make capital transfers with- out restriction to other Sterling Area countries, except Hong Kong (see section on Exchange Control Territory, above). All capital transfers by residents to countries outside the Sterling Area require approval. For security reasons, no capital transfers are allowed to Rhodesia, whether in the fo rm of direct investment or of the purchase of Rhodesian securities, or by any other means. For direct investments outside the Sterling Area, off ic ial exchange is not made available. Such direct investments may, with authorization, be financed with invest- ment currency or by suitable long-term borrowing outside the Sterling Area. The purchase of foreign currency securities outside the Sterling Area must also be financed with investment currency or, in some cases, by long-term borrowing outside the Sterling Area. The purchase by U.K. residents of a house or apartment for personal use in countries outside the Sterling Area requires specific approval and must either be made f rom another U.K. resident for sterling or from a nonresident with property currency; payment for attendant expenses and improve- ments, but not maintenance, must also be made with property currency. Approval is normally limited to one property a fam i ly, and purchases of property currency are limited to reasonable amounts. Payments to nonresident beneficiaries are authorized freely in respect of inheritances due f rom the estates of deceased residents: so also are capital payments under l i fe and other insurance policies taken up by nonresidents with resident insurance companies. A direct investment by a nonresident made af ter Janua ry 1, 1950 with the approval of the exchange control authorities may be sold or otherwise liquidated, and the entire proceeds thereof, including any capital appreciation, which are due to the nonresident may be repatriated at any time. Payments abroad that are due to a nonresident in respect of matured capital obligations are also permitted. Other payments in respect of nonresident-owned capital investment, except that owned by residents of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, are normally credited to Blocked Accounts. Foreign-owned firms and foreign individuals must obtain Treasury permission in order to raise capital in the United Kingdom, and U.K. resident subsidiaries of foreign companies are required to obtain con- sent from the Treasury before borrowing in the United Kingdom or before issuing shares or other securities to nonresidents. Such per- mission is normally given for borrowing for the purpose of financing the company's day-to-day business, but is not normally given for any expansion of manufac tur ing capacity except for companies whose activities are regarded as bringing special advantages to the U.K. economy. 582 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM Transactions in securities of all types may be carried out freely between residents of the United Kingdom. Residents are permitted, subject to certain conditions, to sell foreign currency securities outside the Sterling Area, and, af ter 25 per cent of the proceeds has been sold to an authorized bank at the off ic ial market rate of exchange, to reinvest the balance of the exchange proceeds (investment currency) in other marketable foreign currency securities, or to sell the exchange to other residents for such investments or for approved direct investments outside the Sterling Area. When fore ign currency securities are sold on a U.K. stock exchange for sterling, an amount of investment cur- rency in the fo rm of specified currency equivalent to 25 per cent of the sale proceeds must be purchased in the investment currency market for resale to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange. Professional dealers mak ing a "book" and certain other operators may on application be exempt from the 25 per cent requirement for certain of their operations. Investment currency held for a continuous period of six months ceases to be investment currency unless an amount of investment currency in the fo rm of specified currency equivalent to 25 per cent of the amount held is, at the end of each six-month period, sold to an authorized bank at the off ic ial market rate of exchange.12 U.K. investment trusts are permitted, subject to certain conditions, to borrow foreign currency outside the Sterling Area at long term, for the purpose of making portfolio investments in foreign currency securities. U.K. jobbers and other security dealers may, with permis- sion, arrange day-to-day borrowing of foreign currency, whether f rom U.K. banks or from nonresidents, to finance a "book" in foreign cur- rency securities, but not to finance holdings of such securities as investments. Residents of other parts of the Sterling Area are not prevented by the U.K. regulations f rom buy ing and selling sterling and Rhodesian securities in the United Kingdom, but they must obtain the permission of the U.K authorities to buy and sell other securities in the United Kingdom. Permission is required for all transfers of securities in the United Kingdom in which a nonresident is involved as either transferor or transferee, but most transfers are covered by a general authority. U.K. companies do not require prior authorization to issue sterling bearer securities. 12 Investment currency may be invested temporarily in short-term government bonds (with up to six months to run before final ma tu r i ty) or in six-month Treasury bills or other forms of recognized short-term money market paper with- out incurring the need to comply with the 25 per cent requirement on resale of the paper. 583 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM Nonresidents except Rhodesian residents may buy any securities on a recognized stock exchange in the United Kingdom against payment f rom an External Accoun t; against payment f rom a Blocked Account they may buy most sterling securities. Securities so purchased may be exported from the United Kingdom. Foreign currency securities may be sold by nonresidents on a stock exchange in the United Kingdom for settlement only in foreign currency. In no circumstances may settle- ment be in sterling. Nonresidents must obtain permission to buy securities in the United Kingdom other than on a stock exchange, whether or not the securities are quoted on a stock exchange. Non- residents other than Rhodesian residents may sell sterling securities in the United Kingdom, provided that the proceeds are credited to a Blocked Account or reinvested in a sterling security having at least five years to maturity (special facilities apply to residents of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden). Interest, dividends, etc., f rom such securities and the proceeds at maturity of any that are redeemable may be remitted to the country of residence (except Rhodesia) of the owner or credited to an External Account. Warrants issued by registrars, company secretaries, and paying agents in respect of capital payments on matured securities registered in the names of nonresidents other than Rhodesian residents may be dispatched freely to addressees outside the Sterling Area, and these warrants may be paid by crediting sterling to an External Account. Changes during 1965 During the year the Capital Issues Committee looked more carefully at applications for borrowing in the United Kingdom by overseas residents, including borrowing to finance direct investments in the Sterling Area. January 1. Additional imports from Japan were freed from individual licensing. January 19. Details were released of the tax rebate scheme for exports that was announced in October 1964. The rates of the rebate would for the various industry groups range between 1 per cent and 3 /4 per cent, with an average of about 1.9 per cent. March 15. Imports of refined sugar required a specific import license. Imports of nonfissile radioactive material were freed from specific licensing control. April 7. The regulations concerning the investment currency market were changed. When U.K. residents (or other Sterling Area residents operating through U.K. banks or brokers) sold or presented for redemption foreign currency securities, whether in the United Kingdom 584 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM or outside the Sterling Area, the equivalent in specified currency of 25 per cent of the proceeds had, with a few exceptions, to be exchanged for sterling at the official market rate of exchange; the balance of the proceeds continued to be available as investment currency. This 25 per cent requirement also applied to the sale or liquidation proceeds of direct investments outside the Sterling Area. The following categories of foreign currency accruals to Sterling Area residents no longer were eligible for disposal through the investment currency market: (1) g if ts and charitable donations; (2) receipts under wills and trusts; (3) assets acquired by "exempted fore ign nationals" a f ter they were designated residents of the United Kingdom; and (4) restitution payments. A property currency market was established. U.K. residents (or other Sterling Area residents operating through U.K. banks or brokers) could no longer buy property outside the Sterling Area with investment currency. Except when such property was being purchased f rom another U.K. resident for sterling, residents could use only the proceeds of the sale outside the Sterling Area of property situated outside the Sterling Area and already under U.K. ownership. Foreign currency borrowing was no longer permitted for private purchases of such property. The criteria for the allocation of official exchange for direct invest- ment projects outside the Sterling Area were made more stringent. Japanese yen and Spanish pesetas were added to the list of specified currencies. All securities payable or optionally payable in a specified currency were designated as prescribed securities. The requirement that sterling securities must, if purchased in the Sterling Area for non- residents, be paid for with External Account sterling if these securities were also prescribed securities was amended to permit purchase with Blocked Account sterling. A stricter control was imposed on the issue and use of foreign exchange for all forms of travel outside the Sterling Area, but genuine travel expenditure remained unrestricted. The amount of sterling bank- notes that travelers could take out was reduced from £50 to £25. The customs authorities intensified their checks to ensure that export proceeds were received in the proper form and within the proper period. April 8. The Secretary of State for Economic A f fa i rs addressed a letter to the chairmen of some 300 leading companies urging industry to cut back overseas investment projects that would not yield quick or substantial returns to the balance of payments. It was also suggested that a greater proportion of overseas earnings be remitted to the United Kingdom. April 28. The temporary import charge was reduced to 10 per cent. 585 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM May 4. The Bank of England announced that it was prepared to consider applications on behalf of residents of the United Kingdom or of other parts of the Sterling Area to treat as investment currency, subject to fu lf i l lment of the 25 per cent requirement, capital funds accruing in foreign currency and fa l l ing into the following categories: (1) the proceeds of sale or liquidation of direct investments outside the Sterling A rea; (2) cash balances of immigrants on redesignation as residents of the Sterling A rea; (3) savings from earnings of residents of the Sterling Area who have been employed outside the Sterling Area for not less than two years immediately prior to the application; (4) the capital proceeds of l i fe and endowment policies; and (5) other items of a capital nature, except gifts, charitable donations, capital distribu- tions under wills or trusts, and restitution payments. The distinction, for purposes of reinvestment of investment currency in foreign currency securities, between the proceeds of prescribed and nonprescribed securities was removed. Investment currency could temporarily be invested in short-term paper without incurring the need to comply with the 25 per cent requirement on resale of such paper. Investment currency held a f ter May 4 for a continuous period of six months would cease to be investment currency, unless an amount of investment currency in the fo rm of specified currency equivalent to 25 per cent of the amount held was, at the end of each six-month period, sold to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange. The 25 per cent requirement had to be fu l f i l led on all sales for sterling as investment currency of investment currency acquired af ter May 4. Instructions were issued concerning the calculation and fu lf i l lment of the 25 per cent requirement. When the investment currency to be purchased was different f rom that realized on sale, the conversion rate would be the cross rate in the off ic ial market, but where no rate was available in the official markets in the United Kingdom or elsewhere, the free market rate abroad could be used. July 27. The allocation of o f f ic ial exchange for direct investment outside the Sterling Area was suspended; such investment had to be financed with investment currency or by borrowing outside the Sterling Area. July 27. The Governor of the Bank of England, in a letter to the banks, stated the o f f ic ial aim of limiting to the greatest possible extent facilities for financing imports of manu fac tu red goods for home con- sumption and imports for stockbuilding, and requested the banks to scrutinize with greater care all requests for credit when there was prima fac ie evidence that its purpose was to facilitate payment for imports. 586 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM July 29. The following categories of foreign currency accruals to Sterling Area residents no longer were eligible for disposal through the investment currency market: (1) cash balances of immigrants (including "exempted foreign nationals") who wrere redesignated as Sterling Area residents on or a f ter July 29, 1965; (2) savings from earnings of persons who had been employed outside the Sterling A rea; (3) the capital proceeds of l i fe and endowment policies; and (4) mineral rights. All foreign currency securities held by immigrants at the time of their redesignation on or a f ter July 29, 1965 as residents of the United Kingdom must be placed in restricted deposit, except those for which the owner was granted exemption on the grounds of his nationality; applications to permit their placing in clean deposit, which makes the proceeds eligible for disposal through the investment currency market, would not be considered until two years af ter redesignation. During the two-year period, permission to dispose of the securities normally would not be given unless an amount of investment currency equivalent to the sale proceeds or value of the securities was sold to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange. The same provisions applied to (1) foreign currency securities held at redesignation by immigrants into other parts of the Sterling Area, if the securities were held or taken into deposit by an authorized depository in the United Kingdom, and (2) foreign currency securities purchased outside the Sterling Area with savings from earnings of Sterling Area residents who had been employed outside the Area for at least three years (when the period spent abroad was less, disposal at other than the off ic ial market rate of exchange would not normally be a l lowed). Comparable treatment was given to the assets of "exempted foreign nationals" designated residents of the United Kingdom on or af ter July 29, 1965. Advance payments for imports required the approval of the Bank of England; approval was granted in all cases where the payment was considered genuine and in accordance with the traditions of the trade and the continuance of the practice was considered to be essential. Previously t imports covered by a valid import license could be paid for at any time on production of evidence of purchase and of value of the goods. Forward purchases of foreign currency exceeding the equivalent of £250 for imports required exchange control approval; the supervision of the granting of forward cover by U.K. banks on merchan t ing transactions also was tightened. The general permission to banks to grant loans to corporate bodies resident in the Sterling Area and controlled by nonresidents was withdrawn. The approval of the Bank of England was required before any new loans or any increase in existing loans were granted, or 587 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM Treasury bills or securities were lent, by U.K. residents to corporate bodies and branches (other than banks) resident in the Sterling Area which were directly or indirectly controlled by persons resident outside the Sterling Area; sterling loans and overclrafts to most categories of such corporate bodies and branches would henceforth be normally granted only for day-to-day borrowing for working capital purposes, but existing loan facilities could be continued for a reasonable period until alternative arrangements could be made. November 11. Following its unilateral declaration of independence, Rhodesia was excluded from the Sterling Area. Rhodesian pounds became a foreign currency for the purposes of the Exchange Control Act, and dealings in Rhodesian pounds in the United Kingdom were restricted. Persons resident in Rhodesia and their accounts were excluded from certain exemptions normally available to other non- residents and their accounts. The sterling accounts of residents of Rhodesia maintained in the United Kingdom were redesignated as Rhodesian Accounts; the opening of these accounts required the approval of the Bank of Eng land, and all credits arid debits to such accounts required Treasury permission. Payments from Rhodesian Accounts to External Accounts would not be allowed. Payments by U.K. residents to residents of Rhodesia could be made only in sterling to Rhodesian Accounts. U.K. exports to Rhodesia had to be paid for in External Account sterling, Rhodesian Account sterling, or in a specified currency. Securities payable in Rhodesian pounds became foreign cur- rency securities, unless they were also payable in a Sterling Area currency, in which case they remained sterling securities; purchases of such foreign currency securities by U.K. residents f rom nonresidents and from residents of other parts of the Sterling Area would not normally be authorized. Existing general permissions for transactions in any securities held for residents of Rhodesia were withdrawn. Restrictions were imposed on transactions by U.K. residents in securities payable in Rhodesian pounds. Restrictions also were placed on transactions in gold and Treasury bills held for the account of Rhodesian residents. Permissions covering the establishment of credits and the granting of loans and overdrafts were withdrawn, but existing irrevocable credits could be honored and a general permission was given to open credits when direct exports to Rhodesia were involved. Permission was given to credit certain current and capital items accruing to residents of Rhodesia to Rhodesian Accounts or Rhodesian Blocked Sterling Accounts as appropriate, but the sale proceeds of Rhodesian-owned sterling securities and Rhodesian Blocked Account sterling could not be dealt with as "security sterling." All imports f rom and all exports to Rhodesia required individual licenses; most imports were subsequently prohibited. British Commonwealth preference on 588 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM goods of Rhodesian origin was suspended. Rhodesia was no longer allowed access to the London capital market. November 11. All licenses to deal in Rhodesian currency, including banknotes, were revoked. November 23. Cash gifts f rom U.K. residents to residents of Rhodesia were restricted to an aggregate of £50 a donor from November 11 until further notice. December 1. In addition to the existing prohibition on the transfer of capital from the United Kingdom to Rhodesia, most current pay- ments by U.K. residents to Rhodesian residents, except those in respect of permitted trade, were prohibited; the existing permissions relating to payments in respect of travel, wages and salaries, and contractual commitments such as pensions, interest, and dividends were withdrawn, and sums due to residents of Rhodesia in respect thereof would be held back. Payments in sterling to and from Rhodesian Accounts continued to be allowed in respect of trade, including any relative freight and insurance costs, directly between Rhodesia and the Sterling Area when such trade was permitted by the territory concerned, but U.K. residents could no longer merchant goods between Rhodesia and any other country. Payment for exports f rom the United Kingdom to Rhodesia had to be made in fu ll before shipment. U.K. firms could not normally make remittances to subsidiaries or branches in Rhodesia, and no U.K. bank facilities were allowed to or in favor of residents of Rhodesia. Facilities for travel to Rhodesia were limited to approved official or business purposes. All security transactions in which residents of Rhodesia were in any way concerned had to be referred to the Bank of England. December 3. The U.K. Government suspended f rom office all members of the Board of the Reserve Bank of Rhodesia and appointed other persons to act in their place. Central banks were advised that all authorities of, or given by, the previous Governor and Directors were canceled. December 6. An Order in Council established that banks in the United Kingdom holding Rhodesian bank assets could be required by the Treasury to supply informa t ion about such assets. December 7. Existing general permissions concerning travel outside the Sterling Area were withdrawn insofar as they would relate (1) to travel to Rhodesia, or (2) to persons normally resident in Rhodesia who were temporarily in the United Kingdom. All applications for travel to Rhodesia had to be submitted to the Bank of England. In general, applications for travel exchange by residents of the United Kingdom or the rest of the Sterling Area were authorized up to £250 a 589 ©International Monetary Fund. Permitted payments to persons resident in Rhodesia made through the United Kingdom on behalf of residents of any country could be made only in sterling to Rhodesian Accounts. When permission for payments to persons resident in Rhodesia was withheld, monies due could not be disbursed or used in any way, except for credit to Suspense Accounts and for payment of U.K. income tax and safe custody charges on the monies in question. All existing Bank of England authorities for continuing payments to Rhodesian Accounts for such purposes as pensions, wages, salaries, alimony, annuities, and income under trusts were revoked. The lists of permitted credits and debits to Rhodesian Accounts were revised; no permission would be given for debits in payment of exports to Rhodesia from any country outside the Sterling Area. New regulations concerning transactions in securities by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia were issued. Income and capital repayments on securities held for, or owned by, residents of Rhodesia could no longer be credited to Rhodesian Accounts or Rhodesian Blocked Sterling Accounts but had to be paid into Suspense Accounts. Subject to the rules applicable to sterling securities, Rhodesian securi- ties could be dealt in between U.K. residents and could be bought by residents of any other country except Rhodesia (sales by residents of such countries were permitted subject to additional sa fegua rds ). No credit or guarantee facilities of any kind could be granted to residents of Rhodesia. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES Exchange Rate System The par value of the United States Dollar is 15%! grains of gold %0 fine, which is equivalent to US$35 per fine ounce, at which price (exclusive of hand l ing charges and expenses) the Treasury buys gold f rom both off ic ial and nonoff ic ial sources and sells it abroad only to governments, central banks, and, under certain circumstances, inter- national institutions, for the settlement of in terna t ional balances and other legitimate monetary purposes. There are no restrictions on foreign payments, except those imposed for security reasons on transactions involving the authorities or nationals of Ma in land China, Cuba, North Korea, and North Viet-Nam. The United States notified the Fund on December 10, 1946 that it was prepared to accept the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Controls The Treasury Department deals with license applications for trans- actions invo lv ing the authorities or nationals of Mainland China, North Korea, and North Viet-Nam, as specified under the Foreign Assets Control Regulations; it is also in charge of licensing transactions involving the authorities or nationals of Cuba, under the Cuban Assets Control Regulations. The Bureau of Customs of the Treasury Depart- ment administers import quotas for certain commodities. Import quotas on specified dairy products and certain wheat and wheat products are administered by the Department of Agriculture through the issuance of import licenses and special permits, respectively. The import quota on sugar is prorated among eligible importers under regulations administered by the Department of Agriculture. Licenses for imports of crude petroleum and most petroleum products are issued by the Department of the Interior. For items subject to export control (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, be low ), the Department of Commerce is, in general, the responsible authority. Imports and Import Payments Imports of merchandise known or believed to be of Mainland Chinese, Cuban, North Korean, or North Vietnamese origin, Chinese- type merchandise from other areas, as well as all goods containing Cuban components, and all goods imported f rom or through Ma in land China, Cuba, North Korea, or North Viet-Nam are subject to license. Import quotas are in effec t, pursuant to Section 22 of the Agricultural Adjustment Act, as amended, for cotton, certain cotton waste, and cotton products, wheat and wheat products, specified dairy products, 592 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES and peanuts. With the exception of the import quotas for peanuts and certain cotton and cotton products, the quotas above and those for sugar (pursuant to special legislation) are on a coun try-of-produc t ion basis. Under the Philippines Trade Agreement Revision Act of 1955, import duties applicable to the Philippines are 20 per cent of the general most-favored-nation rate on all products; imports of Philippine cordage, along with sugar, are subject to absolute quotas; and for Philippine cigars, tobacco, coconut oil, and buttons, the preferen t ial tar iff rate applies only to a specific quantity of imports. The U i i ted States is a party to the Long-Term Cotton Textiles Arrangement. The Arrangement authorizes importing countries to request exporting countries to limit or restrain exports of cotton textiles under specified conditions. The United States has concluded compre- hensive bilateral agreements with respect to the cotton textile trade with certain ma jor supplying countries, as well as a limited number of restraint arrangements with certain other countries for specific cotton textile products. In most of these instances, the exporting country limits its exports of cotton textiles to the U.S. ma rke t; in a few cases, the United States has imposed import restrictions. Global quotas are imposed on imports of crude petroleum and petroleum products, except those imported overland (i.e., by pipeline, motor carrier, or r a i l ), which are not restricted. Payments and t rans fe rs abroad may be made freely, with certain exceptions which are permitted only under license: these are payments to or for the account of the authorities or nationals of Mainland China, Cuba, North Korea, and North Viet-Nam. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports (except designated nonstrategic goods) to countries in the European Soviet bloc (except Poland and Rumania) and all exports (except publications and, to Cuba, limited gift parcels) to Mainland China, Cuba, North Korea, and North Viet-Nam are subject to vali- dated licenses. Exports of designated strategic materials to other countries (except Canada) also require validated licenses. The licens- ing requirements applicable to Poland and Rumania are less restric- tive than those applicable to other European Soviet-bloc countries. Exports of certain commodities to all destinations have from time to time been subject to control for supply reasons. Copper is the only commodity presently under "short supply" export control. The ship- ment of arms, ammunition, and petroleum products to Rhodesia has been prohibited. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. 593 ©International Monetary Fund. U.S. purchasers of fo re ign securities are subject to an Interest Equalization Tax of 15 per cent for certain acquisitions of stock and 1.05 per cent to 15 per cent, depend ing on maturity, for certain acquisitions of debt obligations, inc lud ing bank loans, with a period rema in ing to maturity of one year or more. M a jor exemptions f rom the tax are direct investments, investments in less developed countries, the purchase of original or new issues when the President of the United States determines that the application of the tax will have such consequences for a foreign country as to imperil the stability of the international monetary system, and purchases from other U.S. holders. A voluntary fore ign credit restraint program has resulted in the establishment of "guidelines" for banks, for nonbank financial institutions, and for nonf inanc ial business. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA Exchange Rate System No par value for the currency of Upper Volta has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the CFA f r an c, which is offi- cially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French f r an c, giving the relationship CFAF 246.853 = US$1.1 Exchange transactions in French f rancs between the Banque Centrale des Etats deTAfr ique de POuest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at rates resulting f rom the relation CFAF 1 = 0.02 French f rancs, plus or minus a commission if an inward or outward t rans fer is involved. Exchange rates for other currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French f r a nc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned, and include a commission. An exchange tax is payable on all payments equivalent to more than CFAF 10,000 to countries outside the French Franc Area, except pay- ments made by the Government and those related to exports. The tax is as fo l lows: Tax CFAF 250 CFAF 1,000 CFAF 1,500 CFAF 2,500 CFAF 3,000 CFAF 3,500 Payable on CFAF 10,001-25,000 CFAF 25,001-100,000 CFAF 100,001-300,000 CFAF 300,001-500,000 CFAF 500,001-1,000,000 Amounts over CFAF. 1,000,000 Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Exchange Office. Exchange transactions are hand led by the commercial banks under the direction of the Exchange Off ice. Import and export licenses are issued by the Department of Commerce; the former require the approval of the Exchange Office when they are issued for countries outside the French Franc Area. Import certificates are issued free ly by the Exchange Office. Prescription of Currency Upper Volta is a member of the French Franc Area, and settlements with other countries in the French Franc Area are made in any cur- 1The CFA f ranc circulating in Upper Volta is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de I'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Dahomey, Ivory Coast, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 597 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA rency of that Area. Settlements with other countries are usually made through banks in France, in any of the currencies of those countries — provided that the currencies are quoted on the Paris exchange market —or through Foreign Accounts in Convertible Francs. There is an inoperative bilateral payments arrangement with Ghana. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France, but in Upper Volta these accounts have only limited importance. Imports and Import Payments Imports from countries in the French Franc Area may be made freely. Most imports from other countries are subject to licensing; they are admitted in accordance with an annual import program, determined each year by a jo int French-Upper Volta Committee. Under this program, global quotas are established for imports from EEC countries other than France and for imports from most other countries outside the French Franc Area. The quotas fix the limits up to which import licenses are issued for specified commodities to licensed traders. For certain goods admitted without quantitative restriction, certificates of importation arfe issued. The import license or import certificate entitles the importer to purchase the necessary exchange, provided that the required documents (to prove that an order has been placed) are submitted to the author- ized bank. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to countries in the French Franc Area are permitted f ree ly; those to other countries are, in principle, subject to the approval of the Exchange Office, but the authority for such approval has been delegated to authorized banks. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents from profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted freely when the basic transaction has been approved. The allowance for tourist travel is CFAF 250,000 for each trip, and exchange for business travel expenses is freely granted. Foreign workers may repatriate up to 100 per cent of their salaries. Payments for other invisibles are subject to administrative decision. Travelers to other countries of the West Afr ican Monetary Union (Dahomey, Ivory Coast, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal, and Togo) may take out, without limit, banknotes issued by any bank of issue within 598 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA the French Franc Area. Travelers going direct to other countries in the Area may take out, without limit, banknotes issued by any bank of issue in the Area, with the exception of those issued by the BCEAO, for which the limit is CFAF 75,000. Travelers going to countries out- side the French Franc Area may take out in banknotes or coins up to a maximum of F 1,000 in metropolitan francs, or up to 75,000 in CFA or CFP francs, or up to the equivalent of F 750 in notes and coins denominated in any French Franc Area currency other than the French franc. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign banknotes and coins up to the amount declared by them on entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to countries of the French Franc Area may be made free ly but for statistical purposes require a license from the Commerce Office. Exports to all other countries are permitted freely, provided that the exporter undertakes to surrender the exchange proceeds. Certain commodities on the prohibited list can be exported in special circumstances only, and they require a license issued by the Depart- ment of Commerce or the competent ministry. Export proceeds in currencies of countries outside the French Franc Area that are not used to make authorized payments abroad must be surrendered within a month f rom the date of their receipt. Proceeds from Invisibles All amounts due in respect of services f rom residents of countries outside the French Franc Area, and all income exceeding the equivalent of CFAF 25,000 f rom foreign securities, must be collected, and they must be surrendered within one month of receipt. Travelers from other countries of the West A f r ican Monetary Union (Dahomey, Ivory Coast, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal, and Togo) may bring in any amount of CFA banknotes issued by the BCEAO. Travelers from other countries may bring in up to CFAF 75,000 in banknotes issued by the BCEAO. All travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by a bank of issue of the French Franc Area other than the BCEAO, as well as any amount of banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area. The import of Guinean and Malian currency is prohibited. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA Law No. 25/61/AN of July 1961 and Law No. 14/62/AN of June 1962 provide preferential treatment for foreign investment in Upper Volta. Under the latter law, two preferential categories (A and B) are established, in accordance with which preferential treatment with respect to stable rates of taxes, duties, and other fiscal charges may be accorded to specified, approved enterprises for periods of up to 30 years. The benefits under Category B are far more liberal than those under Category A; they are negotiated between the investor and the Government; and the enterprise accorded such benefits must be of special importance to the national economy. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY Exchange Rate System On October 7, 1960, a par value for the Uruguayan Peso was estab- lished by Uruguay with the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. Certain exchange transactions take place in an official exchange market conducted by the Bank of the Republic; from time to time the Bank adjusts its fixed buying and selling rates. The proceeds from basic exports must be surrendered to the Bank of the Republic, which sells exchange for a limited range of official payments. All other permitted exchange transactions take.place in an interbank free market (parallel market) with a freely fluctuating rate. On December 31, 1965, the official buying and selling rates of the Bank of the Republic were Ur$58.90 and Ur$59.90 per US$1, respectively, while the interbank free market rate was about Ur$64.00 per US$1. A tax of %0 of 1 per cent is payable on all funds received f rom abroad and, with minor exceptions, on all funds remitted abroad for purposes other than payments for imports. The proceeds of most exports are subject to taxes (detracciones), and many imports are subject to surcharges. Administration of Control Exchange transactions are carried out through the authorized banks and the I^ank of the Republic. The Bank of the Republic collects import surcharges and export taxes, holds the prepayments and advance deposits required for many imports, and receives export and import registrations. Prescription of Currency Settlements with countries with which Uruguay has bilateral pay- ments agreements are made through accounts maintained in U.S. dollars as the accounting unit.1 Settlements with other countries are made in U.S. dollars or other convertible currencies. Imports and Import Payments All imports are subject to registration with the Bank of the Republic prior to placing orders abroad.2 Imports of certain goods 1 These countries are Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Poland, and Spain. 2 On October 18, 1965, the Bank of the Republic suspended for 180 days the acceptance of import registrations for commodities subject to a surcharge of 60 per cent or more, with the exception of certain industrial materials not produced in Uruguay. At the end of the year, imports of certain other goods also remained suspended. 601 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY not included in the lists of freely permitted imports are prohibited; with these exceptions, imports are not subject to quantitative restric- tion. Exchange at the off ic ial rate is granted by the Bank of the Republic for certain imports of the Government and of public entities and for a few private imports that are considered indispensable. Exchange for all other imports must be obtained in the parallel market. Imports are classified in seven categories: goods in one category are not subject to surcharge; goods in the other six categories are subject to a surcharge of 30, 60, 90, 150, 225, or 300 per cent, which is payable at the time of registration. With the exception mainly of certain capital goods that cannot be registered unless they are financed abroad for a period of at least 3 years, all imports require prepayment of the equivalent of the c.i.f. value in Uruguayan pesos; the prepayment must be lodged with the Bank of the Republic at the time of registration and is re fundab le on application a f ter 8 months. For goods subject to the 150, 225, or 300 per cent surcharge, an advance deposit of 200 per cent is also required. The advance deposit must be made with the Bank of the Republic at the time the import is registered; it is refunded 9 months later or, for imports of a few specified items and imports of all goods not specifically listed, 12 months later. Imports of all items appearing in the Uruguayan concession list for trade with LAFTA countries or the special concession lists for Ecuador and Paraguay are exempt from advance deposit requirements; some of these items are also exempt f rom surcharges but are subject to the prepayment requirements, while the rest are subject to reduced percentages. All imports are subject, in addition to any customs duty required, to additional import duties ranging f rom 1.5 per cent to 15 per cent of the c.i.f. value and payable upon customs clearance. All imports valued at over US$1.82 are subject to consular charges of %0 of 1 per cent on the peso amount resulting f rom conversion of the f.o.b. value at a rate of Ur$18 per US$1;3 the amount of the charges is payable in foreign exchange, at a rate of Ur$l = US$2.10. Prepayments, advance deposits, and surcharges in most cases are calculated on average c.i.f. prices (aforos) established for many com- modities or on the actual c .i .f. value, whichever is higher. In a few cases, the calculation is based on an off ic ia l ly assessed price (also referred to as aforo), wh ich usually is expressed in U.S. dollars per kilogram. Imports ordinarily subject to the 30 per cent surcharge are liable to only two thirds of this surcharge if transported in Uruguayan ships. ?0n January 1, 1966 this conversion rate was changed to Ur$55 per US$1. 602 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles may be made freely, subject to a tax of %0 of 1 per cent. Exchange for invisibles must be obtained in the parallel market. Companies constituted outside Uruguay are required to pay a 4 per cent tax on income accruing in Uruguay and a further 10 per cent when transferr ing this income f rom Uruguay. There are no limitations on the export of foreign or domestic banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds The proceeds of most exports are subject to taxes (detracciones or retentions), which are withheld by the Bank of the Republic. For some commodities, the tax is stipulated in pesos by unit of export com- modity, but it may not be more than 50 per cent or less than 0.01 per cent of the peso proceeds of the export, except that for exports of greasy wool the stipulated minimum is 25 per cent, while for washed and scoured wool, tops, wool yarn, and the by-products of combing and spinning it is 5 per cent; these percentages may be adjusted at 60-day intervals. The exchange proceeds of exports subject to taxes must be surrendered in fu ll to the Bank of the Republic, through banks authorized to deal in foreign exchange, not later than 10 working days after shipment has been authorized. For exports of wool and meat, minimum f.o.b. values (minimum surrender prices or aforos) expressed in U.S. dollars per kilogram have been established for various grades and types. For wool, the minimum f.o.b. values per kilogram are as follows: US$1.20 for greasy wool; US$1.85 for scoured wool; US$1.51 for scoured skirtings; US$2.00 for tops; and US$0.60 for noil and combing by-products. Exports of worsted cloth and clothing receive a 22 per cent export subsidy on the f.o.b. value. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA Exchange Rate System The par value established with the Fund is Bolivares 3.35 = US$1. Exchange transactions take place at the following rates. The Central Bank of Venezuela purchases proceeds of the petroleum and iron ore exporting companies at the rate of Bs 4.40 per US$1. Most other exchange proceeds are purchased by commercial banks at rates close to Bs 4.48 per US$1. Proceeds f rom exports of cacao and coffee may be purchased also by the Central Bank at the rate of Bs 4.485 per US$1; in certain circumstances they are eligible for special subsidies (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, be low ). The Central Bank sells exchange to the Government and its agencies and to the commercial banks at Bs 4.485 per US$1. Commercial banks sell exchange to the public at Bs 4.50 per US$1 for all transactions. The Central Bank, through its Import Subsidy Office, grants a subsidy of Bs 1.15 per US$1 on exchange purchased to make payments for imports of wheat and powdered milk. Administration of Control Import and export licenses, when required, are generally issued by the Ministries of Development or Agriculture, depending on the commodity. Under the terms of an agreement between the Ministry of Finance and the Central Bank, the latter has the responsibility of ensuring that a subsidy is applied to the appropriate transactions; the Import Subsidy Office of the Central Bank administers the payment of this subsidy, which is granted only on import payments for wheat and powdered milk (see section on Exchange Rate System, above). Imports of these products require both an import license from the Ministry of Development and a permit from the Import Subsidy O f f ice; exports containing a substantial component of wheat or powdered milk also require a permit f rom the Import Subsidy Office. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Imports and Import Payments Certain goods either are prohibited or may be imported only by the Government. Many textiles and a number of other items require import licenses; quantitative restrictions are maintained on these items for protective purposes. Import licenses for some products are issued on the condition that the importer has purchased domestic products equal to a prescribed percentage of the amount imported. 609 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA Imports eligible for the subsidy of Bs 1.15 (wheat and powdered milk) require permits from the Import Subsidy Office and import licenses from the Ministry of Development. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles may be made f ree ly; exchange for this purpose is purchased f rom commercial banks. Exports and Export Proceeds Licenses for the export of some products essential to the domestic economy must be obtained f rom the Ministries of Development and Agriculture. Export permits f rom the Import Subsidy Office are also required if commodities eligible for the Bs 1.15 subsidy are a sub- stantial component of the export. The export of gold requires an export license issued by the Ministry of Finance. The petroleum and iron ore exporting companies must surrender to the Central Bank export pro- ceeds, to the extent of their local currency requirements (including taxes), at a rate of Bs 4.40 per US$1. Exporters of coffee and cacao may sell exchange proceeds to the Central Bank at Bs 4.485 per US$1; they may receive an additional payment for this exchange, calculated to prevent the f.o.b. bolivar prices of these products in Venezuelan ports f rom fa l l ing below specified m in imum amounts regardless of external dollar prices. On the basis of the prices existing during 1965, such additional payments were being made only for export proceeds derived f rom the lower grades of cacao. The export of strategic materials to certain countries is prohibited. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts f rom invisibles are freely disposable. Capital All capital transfers are permitted freely. There is no registration procedure for incoming capital. Not for Redistribution VIET-NAM 1 Exchange Rate System No par value for the Vietnamese Piastre has been established with the Fund. The off ic ial parity is VN$35.00 per US$1 The off ic ial buying rate is VN$34.65, and the selling rate is VN$35.35, per US$1; these rates are not applicable to any exchange transactions. The official buy- ing and selling rates, plus a premium on purchases of exchange or the payment of a Security and Economic Development Tax on sales of exchange, equivalent in each case to five sevenths of the amount trans- ferred calculated at the off ic ial parity rate, give rise to effective rates of VN$59.65 buying, and VN$60.35 selling, per US$1, for most trade and for certain transactions in invisibles. Other effective rates result f rom a system of subsidies, ranging f rom VN$5.00 to VN$40.00 per US$1, extended to the exchange proceeds of secondary exports, and f rom the existence of an officially controlled free market, through which settlements may be made for certain invisibles. As at December 31, 1965, the rates in the controlled free market were 1 per cent on either side of VN$73.50 per US$1. Most invisibles are settled through a Special Fund at the National Bank. The buying and selling rates of the Special Fund are, respectively, the controlled free market rate plus a special subsidy of VN$44.50 per US$1, and the controlled free market rate plus a special charge of VN$44.50 per US$1; the resulting effective rates as at December 31, 1965 were VN$117.265 buying, and VN$118.735 selling, per US$1. (See Table of Exchange Rates, below.) Under an agreement with Cambodia, payments to and f rom that country are made at a rate of VN$1 — 1 riel. Rates for other currencies are computed on the basis of their off ic ial parities in relation to the effective U.S. dollar rate applied to the transaction concerned. Payments and receipts through the off ic ial market, and outgoing payments for certain invisibles authorized through the controlled free market, must be effected through the authorized exchange banks. Payments and receipts through the Special Fund must be effected through the Directorate-General of Exchange at the National Bank and an authorized bank. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Directorate-General of Exchange of the National Bank of Viet-Nam. Imports under U.S. "project aid" programs require no license but are subject to special contracts or procurement procedures. Licenses for other imports financed with U.S. aid are issued by the Directorate of Foreign Trade and are countersigned by the National Bank (Directorate of External Rela- tions and Foreign A i d ). Licenses for imports f inanced with Viet-Nam's own exchange are issued by the Directorate of Foreign Trade and are countersigned by the Directorate-General of Exchange. However, for imports of a noncommercial character valued at less than VN$1,000, the Directorate-General of Exchange is authorized to grant licenses. Export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Foreign Trade, but they require also the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Prescription of Currency Settlements with Cambodia and the United Arab Republic are made through accounts maintained by the central bank of each country in U.S. dollars and pounds sterling, respectively, and balances thereon are settled periodically in U.S. dollars.2 All other settlements are made in convertible currencies, mainly in U.S. dollars, pounds sterling, or French francs. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may maintain accounts with banks, subject to the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. A category of nonresident accounts, called Capital Accounts, covers piastres owned by nonresident foreigners that may not be transferred abroad. Balances in Capital Accounts may be used for investment in certain areas of economic activity designated by the Ministry of National Economy. Their use is subject to the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Investments financed f rom Capital Accounts generally are not covered by the Investment Law of 1963 (see section on Capital, be low), and proceeds from the liquidation of such investments are credited to Capital Accounts unless the Ministry of National Economy has declared them eligible for the privileges of the law. Balances in Capital Accounts are negotiable between non- resident foreigners. 2 The bilateral payments agreement with the United Arab Republic is due to expire on May 22,1966. 613 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET-NAM Imports and Import Payments Most imports are made in accordance with an annual commercial import program, the bulk of which is divided into three parts: (1) imports financed with funds from the U.S. Agency for International Development (A ID ); (2) imports financed from Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange resources; and (3) "third-country-financed imports," i.e., imports financed with Japanese reparations, French, German, and Japanese loans, or French export credit. In principle, products imported under the AID program are not included among imports that are financed otherwise, and vice versa. However, when AID financing proves insufficient for obtaining imports of essential products, such imports may be financed from Viet-Nam's official exchange reserves. Many imports are prohibited. Licenses for imports of nine groups of commodities 3 are reserved for exporters of goods other than rice and rice products, rubber, cinnamon, buffaloes on the hoof, salt, cigarettes, rice bran oil, and white sand (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, below). The issuance of licenses for most imports from France is suspended. Imports from Cambodia are made on a barter basis (echanges compenses). Some other imports are permitted without foreign exchange (sans devises); these include commodities donated under the Colombo Plan, small donations from countries not participating in that Plan, imports by end-users with branches abroad, gifts and samples, aviation gasoline, lubricants, and spare parts for international airlines, and other small imports, when the Directorate-General of Exchange is satisfied that the foreign exchange privately held by the importer has not been obtained illegally. Imports are classified in 18 broad categories. An importer may make only application to import goods in a specified number of categories. Individual licenses, which are not transferable, are required for all imports. Importers who use less than 90 per cent of a license issued for AID-financed imports or less than 97 per cent of a license issued for imports financed from Viet-Nam's own reserves are subject to a penalty. The penalty in the former case may go up to 20 per cent of the value of the commodities licensed. In the latter case, the penalty is determined by the Directorate-General of Exchange on a case-to-case basis. Exchange is granted for all authorized imports at the official rate plus a Security and Economic Development Tax equal to five sevenths 8 These are maltose and candy, dairy products, fresh and dried fruits, beverages, ginseng and herbs of the traditional pharmacopoeia, woolen blankets and certain piece goods for clothing, cigarette paper and certain other kinds of paper, toys, and cosmetics, 614 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET-NAM of the amount transferred calculated at the official parity rate. For capital goods ordered prior to January 1962, or subsequently with official approval, payment of the tax can be deferred for up to five years. A subsidy of 20 per cent is granted on the c. & f. value (calcu- lated at the rate of VN$60 per U.S. do l lar) of industrial equipment for new approved investments and of accessories and spare parts for existing industrial firms, provided that the import is financed from foreign aid received in the form of grants. An "austerity" tax, ranging f rom 85 per cent to 310 per cent, is charged on the c.i.f. value of nonessential or competitive imports calculated at the o f f ic ia l, rate of exchange. Certain imports also are subject to an "equalization" tax. Payments for Invisibles Most payments for invisibles require approval by the Directorate- General of Exchange; the authorization of some private invisibles settled through the Special Fund is delegated to the authorized banks. For certain government expenses exchange is allocated by the Directorate-General of Exchange at the off ic ial rate plus the Security and Economic Development Tax. With the approval of the Directorate- General of Exchange, payments for certain private invisibles may be made through the controlled free market. Exchange for most private invisibles is sold by the Special Fund at an effective rate of VN$118.735 per US$1. The principal payments that may be made through the controlled free market are government-sponsored students' transfers, family remittances by foreign technicians, and banking commissions. The principal payments settled through the Special Fund are travel expenses, fre igh t, insurance, fam i ly remittances by foreign nationals not recognized as technicians, profits, rents, and private donations. Foreign firms are generally permitted to transfer up to 90 per cent of their net annual profits af ter tax. Profit transfers by foreign enter- prises established or expanded af ter 1963 under the terms of the 1963 Investment Law are governed by the provisions of that law (see section on Capital, below). Resident nationals may once a year acquire from the Special Fund foreign exchange for tourist travel equivalent to US$20 a day, up to the fo l low ing limits: the equivalent of US$1,200 for countries outside the Far East, of US$300 for Hong Kong, Bangkok, and Singa- pore, and of US$600 for other Far Eastern countries; these amounts 615 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET-NAM may be supplemented by the equivalent of US$40 in foreign bank- notes, also to be settled at the Special Fund rate. Travelers are per- mitted to take with them up to VN$500 in Vietnamese banknotes. Foreign exchange not used by foreign travelers may be re-exported when a declaration is made to the customs and evidence is given that any utilized exchange has been sold to an authorized bank at the appropriate rate. Exports and Export Proceeds All permitted exports require a license; they must be registered with an authorized bank, which is responsible for the repatriation of th,e foreign exchange. All exports to communist countries and exports to any destination of manufactured or semimanufactured products originally imported into Viet-Nam, gold, rice, rice products, and certain other items are prohibited. Export proceeds must be surrendered at the official rate; they receive a fixed premium equal to five sevenths of the amount sold calculated at the official parity rate. Many secondary exports benefit from one of 12 subsidies rang ing from VN$5.00 to VN$40.00 per US$1, in addition to the prem ium. Exporters of all goods other than rice and rice products, rubber, cinnamon, buffa loes on the hoof, salt, cigarettes, rice bran oil, and white sand are entitled to receive import licenses corresponding to 25 per cent of their surrendered export proceeds for certain imports which are not otherwise licensed (see section on Imports and Import Payments, above ); these benefits are granted also when the export commodity receives an exchange subsidy. Exports of rubber are subject to an export tax of 40 per cent, and those of duck feathers to a tax of 15 per cent; export taxes are levied on the f.o.b. value calculated at the official rate of exchange. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from trade-connected invisibles must be surrendered at the official rate; they receive a premium equal to five sevenths of the amount sold calculated at the official parity rate. Exchange derived from certain other invisibles and net receipts resulting from certain payments and receipts in foreign exchange which may be entered on "port-of-call" accounts maintained by shipping and airline companies must be sold at the controlled free market rate; thus, philanthropic organizations and foreign embassies must sell their foreign exchange at this rate to cover their expenses in Viet-Nam. Foreign troops and 616 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET-NAM personnel serving in Viet-Nam and tourists may sell exchange at the Special Fund rate; foreign troops, in order to benefit from this rate, must present scrip ("military payment certificates") for conversion into piastres. Travelers entering Viet-Nam may bring in any amount of foreign exchange, but it must be declared to the customs upon entry. A traveler may bring in Vietnamese banknotes up to a total of VN$500. Capital Under general regulations, capital may be imported without formali- ties, but foreign investors must register their capital with the Viet- namese authorities and agree on the terms of the investment in order to be able to repatriate their capital and to transfer profits. Under the Investment Law of 1963, special benefits may be accorded to new foreign investments in the sectors of the economy that are given high priority. Applications must be approved by the interdepartmental Investment Committee. The minimum investment in agriculture was established at VN$0.5 million, and in industry at VN$1 million. Imports of equipment and spare parts needed by foreign undertakings covered by the law are exempt from customs duties. Foreign tech- nicians employed by these enterprises are exempt from income tax for 2 years. Foreign investments are free of taxes on profits, securities, and real estate for specified periods of time. The new investments are not subject to any nationalization measures for the first 15 years from the date of the written authorization granted to the investor; they are accorded the same treatment as that applicable to domestic investments. The law provides for the transfer of profits at an annual rate of up to 20 per cent of the invested capital and for the repatria- tion of the original investment af ter 5 years at an annual rate of up to 20 per cent ( a f t er 20 years for investment of foreign-owned capital previously held in V ie t-Nam). An implementing regulation (Exchange Control Notice No. 73) provides that all imports and exports of capital under the law are to be settled at the controlled free market rate on the day of transfer, with the exception that capital imports in kind must be calculated at the rate of VN$60 per U.S. dollar. Investments not covered by the Investment Law are subject to the regulations and case-to-case decisions of the Directorate-General of Exchange, which authorizes the transfer of up to 90 per cent of net annual profits a f ter taxes but discourages disinvestment. Enter- prises established in 1962 may, subject to the approval of the Invest- ment Committee, be granted the privileges of the Investment Law. 617 ©International Monetary Fund. Changes during 1965 During 1965, there were several modifications of the supplementary export subsidies, the list of minor exports benefiting f rom such sub- sidies, and the imports and exports covered by the special export incentive scheme. September 1. A Special Fund was established at the National Bank to carry out specified exchange transactions at an effective rate of VN$118 per US$1. On the buying side, this rate was applied to exchange sold by nonresident physical persons during their stay in Viet-Nam, and on the selling side to most private invisibles. Foreign troops serving in Viet-Nam were paid in scrip ("military payment certificates") which could only be exchanged for piastres through the Special Fund. Foreign military and civilian personnel no longer were permitted to bring foreign banknotes into Viet-Nam. September 22. Import duties and "austerity" taxes on most imports were increased. October 16. The application of the increases in import duties and "austerity" taxes announced on September 22 was confined to certain nonessential and semiessential goods. 618 ©International Monetary Fund.
