The exchange allocations for tourist travel, business travel, and certain other private invisibles were increased; the per- centages were raised of profits and of foreign workers' salaries that could be remitted. October 20. It was announced that exchange f rom Viet-Nam's own resources would be granted liberally for import payments. NOTE.—The following change took place early in 1966: January 1. With the exception of imports from France and imports effected within the framework of a loan agreement, all imports financed by Viet-Nam's own resources had to be settled in U.S. dollars. 619 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA Exchange Rate System The par value is Yugoslav Dinars 1,250 •= US$1. All exchange transactions take place at rates based on the par value. Administration of Control The Federal Executive Council prescribes the general provisions governing foreign trade and exchange transactions. The Federal Secre- tariat for Foreign Trade, by virtue of these general provisions, estab- lishes rules and regulations and makes decisions governing commercial transactions, and issues import and export licenses when required. The Federal Secretariat for Finance prescribes the specific provisions governing exchange transactions. The National Bank is the operative organ of exchange control and prescribes the methods of payment to and from foreign countries. All foreign exchange transactions must be carried out through the National Bank and the authorized banks, i.e., the Yugoslav Bank for Foreign Trade, the Yugoslav Agricultural Bank, the Republics' Eco- nomic Banks, or, for certain imports of capital goods, the Yugoslav Investment Bank. Most of the foreign exchange resources are controlled by the National Bank, which provides the foreign exchange needed by the authorized banks. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from countries with which Yugoslavia has bilateral payments agreements are made in the currencies and according to the procedures set forth in those agreements. If no agreement exists, settlement is usually made in a convertible currency. Yugoslavia has payments agreements requiring settlements through bilateral clearing accounts as follows: (1) in U.S. dollars with Afghanistan, Albania, Algeria, Brazil, Bulgaria, Cambodia, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Ger- many, Greece, Guinea, Hungary, Israel, Mali, Mongolia, Poland, Rumania, Spain, Tunisia, Turkey, the U.S.S.R., and the United Arab Republic; (2) in sterling with Mainland Ch ina; and (3) in their respec- tive currencies with Ghana, India, Iraq, and Switzerland. A certain degree of multilateralization in payments is provided under the bilateral payments agreements with Iraq, Mali, and Switzerland. Certain settlements with Ceylon, Colombia, Jordan, and Pakistan take place through special accounts. 620 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA Nonresident Accounts There are two types of nonresident dinar accounts. One type may be credited with the dinar countervalue of exchange transferred from abroad, and debited for any current payment in Yugoslavia; balances on this type of account may be transferred abroad. The other type may be credited with dinar amounts realized in Yugoslavia in accordance with the regulations, and may be debited only for tourist and living expenses in Yugoslavia; balances on this type of account may not be transferred abroad except with special approval. Foreigners resident outside Yugoslavia may open accounts in con- vertible currencies in Yugoslavia. Balances on such accounts may be used for both commercial and noncommercial transactions. Foreign missions and foreigners resident in Yugoslavia may open with the National Bank accounts expressed in foreign currencies or dinars. Payments to the credit of such- foreign currency accounts may be made only by transfers of the foreign currency in which the account is denominated. These accounts may be debited for all noncommercial payments. Transfers from the foreign currency accounts are allowed in the currency of the account; transfers f rom accounts in convertible currencies may be made to all countries. Imports and Import Payments Only economic enterprises registered as participating in foreign trade may import. Registration is granted to all enterprises fu l f i l l ing certain prescribed conditions; in addition to enterprises specializing in foreign trade, most large industrial enterprises are registered. Unregistered enterprises are required to give their orders to the foreign trade enterprises, which import on their behalf and on their account. The import of certain basic foodstuffs, such as wheat, lard, edible oil, and sugar, is carried out by a number of foreign trade enterprises acting as agents of the State Food Administration. Eighty-eight commodities or groups of commodities included in a free list may be imported without license from any country and are free of quantitative restriction. This list comprises 77 raw materials and semiprocessed goods and 11 consumer goods items. A "liberal licensing" procedure applies to imports from all sources of 12 com- modities or groups of commodities for which import licenses are issued freely. Imports under these two categories constituted about 24 per cent of all imports in 1965. For imports of 28 commodities or groups of commodities (23 of them being raw materials and semiprocessed goods and the other 5 being broad groups of consumer goods), commodity quotas are estab- 621 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA lished in dinars. The fu ll quota for each commodity or group of com- modities is divided into subquotas: one for all convertible currencies and the others for each bilateral agreement currency. Only a portion of the annual quotas is released initially, and the total of the subsequent releases may be more or less than the remainder after the initial release. Imports under quotas constituted about 34 per cent of all imports in 1965. Capital goods also are imported under quotas established for all convertible currencies taken together and for each bilateral agreement currency. Foreign exchange for this purpose is made available through the Yugoslav Investment Bank, the Yugoslav Agricultural Bank, and the Republics' Economic Banks. In addition, economic enterprises are authorized to import capital goods and spare parts from any country within the limits established for each individual enterprise, on the basis of disposable depreciation funds. Imports of equipment valued at more than US$120,000 may be made only on submission of tenders or on the basis of public bidding. Imports of capital goods under these procedures constituted about 18 per cent of all imports in 1965. Other goods, except consumer goods, may be imported freely from any country by utilizing foreign exchange allocated to each enterprise on the basis of the foreign exchange allocated to it in the past for imports of the same goods; but should an economic enterprise wish to import under this procedure, whether under "liberal licensing," under individual commodity quotas, or under restrictive licensing (see below), it must obtain the necessary import permit or authorization. In practice, the use of these funds for imports of goods under quotas is allowed only in exceptional cases. Liberal treatment is accorded to imports of goods destined for fur ther processing and subsequent export. In practice, this procedure is used mainly for imports of raw materials and semi- manufactured products. Imports under this procedure constituted about 24 per cent of all imports in 1965. Specified raw materials, semimanufactured goods, consumer goods, and specified capital goods may be imported only on the basis of an individual license, which is granted on a restrictive basis on the merits of each case. Imports under this arrangement amounted to less than 1 per cent of all imports in 1965. Foreign exchange appropriate to the exporting country is provided by the National Bank or one of the authorized banks to pay for permitted imports. For the payment of imports subject to restrictive licensing, the economic enterprises may use either the foreign exchange allocated to them on the basis of past use or, for capital goods, the foreign exchange allocation based on the percentage of disposable depreciation funds, or foreign exchange made available to them on an 622 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA ad hoc basis for imports destined for further processing and subsequent exportation. In addition to the above, economic enterprises may obtain foreign exchange for payment of imports under quotas, or of those covered by allocations received on the basis of past use, from the authorized banks' own availabilities, provided that the imports con- cerned are used in such a way as to increase exports. Compensation arrangements with foreign countries are permitted only as an exception and are subject to approval by an authorized bank; in certain cases, this approval requires the prior agreement of the National Bank. Imports through compensation transactions constituted about 0.5 per cent of all imports in 1965. When selling foreign exchange to economic organizations for restricted imports, authorized banks may conclude contracts with them for the sale of foreign exchange over and above the amount fore- seen in the import plan for the commodity concerned; such linking contracts must include an undertaking by the economic organization to effect a specified amount of exports. Imports under linking contracts constituted about 30 per cent of total imports in 1965. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles related to merchandise transactions are treated in a manner similar to that accorded to payments for merchan- dise. Exchange for all payments for invisibles may be purchased from the National Bank by government organs and institutions, social organizations, and similar bodies, within quotas determined in advance for each year. The National Bank may sell foreign exchange up to the equivalent of US$20 for remittances for fam i ly maintenance, court and other fees abroad, certain other purposes, and any personal expenses. There are basic annual exchange allowances of US$20 for tourist travel abroad, and US$10 for private travel to visit relatives abroad, for each person. All other exchange allocations for invisibles must be individually authorized. Not more than Din 5,000 in Yugoslav bank- notes, in denominations of Din 100, may be taken out by travelers. Exports and Export Proceeds Twenty-five industrial commodities or groups of such commodities and 20 agricultural and forest products are subject to individual licensing. Two industrial commodities or groups of such commodities are subject to export quota. The principal reasons for export control are to ensure adequate domestic supplies and to meet obligations aris- ing from agreements relating to imports from the United States under U.S. Public Law 480. 623 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA All proceeds from exports must be surrendered immediately after receipt, and in any event not later than 90 days from the date of exportation. Exporters may purchase from the authorized banks foreign exchange proportionate to their export receipts to make payments connected with their exports, to purchase goods abroad, and to make other payments intended to advance their own economic activities. The proportions of export receipts that may be purchased by exporters vary according to the type of export concerned and range from 3 per cent for agricultural goods to 7 per cent for manufac tured goods of lesser importance, 10 per cent for machinery, and 12 per cent for pharmaceutical products, tractors, and motor vehicles. Tourist offices abroad may repurchase 20 per cent of their earnings, and economic organizations exporting books, periodicals, sheet music, and domestic •films, 25 per cent. The purchased exchange is not transferable to other enterprises. In practice, a large part is used to pay for expenses incidental to exports. Proceeds front Invisibles Proceeds f rom invisibles must be surrendered to the authorized banks; those accruing f rom services must be surrendered not later than 90 days from the date of maturity of the payment. Organizers of international fa i rs in Yugoslavia are credited with 20 per cent of the exchange they receive from foreign exhibitors. This exchange may be used for the purchase of equipment for stands, to pay commissions for representation abroad, and for other expenses connected with the fa irs. Enterprises involved in projects abroad may retain 100 per cent of their exchange proceeds to carry out such projects. Similarly, enterprises that participate in foreign companies may retain their profits earned abroad and use them for reinvestment abroad. Enterprises involved in foreign advertising in Yugoslavia may retain 50 per cent of their exchange receipts for use in connection with their activities, including the purchase abroad of printing machines and other materials. In all these cases the exchange is not transferable, but it can always be sold to the National Bank. If the exchange is used to pay for imports, the usual procedures for import authorisation apply. Residents may be authorized to hold foreign exchange accounts, in which they may deposit savings f rom salaries, per diem reimburse- ments, fellowships, and individual earnings obtained while staying abroad. These accounts are not transferable to other persons or accounts and may be retained for an indefinite period of time; they may be used freely for the personal needs of the account holder and 624 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA of close members of his fam i ly. Assistance, grants, or similar receipts from abroad may in certain cases be used for payments abroad, pro- vided that an application to this effect is submitted to the Federal Secretariat for Finance within one year af ter receipts are obtained. Amounts authorized by the Secretariat may in certain cases be utilized only for direct payments abroad; they may not be credited to a foreign exchange account. Sales of certain manufac tured goods by authorized trade organiza- tions to foreign tourists in Yugoslavia, and to Yugoslav citizens paying in convertible exchange exempt from the surrender requirement, are made at a discount of 10 per cent, representing the exemption f rom turnover taxes. This discount is granted only on purchases in author- ized shops against checks expressed in foreign currencies or against certain foreign banknotes. Not more than Din 10,000 in Yugoslav banknotes, in denominations of Din 100, may be brought in by travelers. Capital All transfers of a capital nature by residents or nonresidents require individual licenses. Authorization is seldom granted for foreign participation in domestic enterprises in Yugoslavia. However, foreign loans to Yugoslav enter- prises are allowed on a liberal basis. Nonresidents (individuals or legal entities) are permitted to purchase and hold real estate property (buildings and land) in Yugoslavia for living, rest, or recuperation purposes, and to rent or lease this property through the intermediary of a Yugoslav tourist office or other Yugoslav authorized organizations. The nonresident purchaser of land must, however, erect a building on his lot within two years f rom the date of purchase. Unless specifically permitted to retain foreign exchange, residents are obliged to repatriate and surrender foreign exchange held abroad. Capital transfers abroad by residents are usually not approved. How- ever, domestic enterprises participating abroad in foreign enterprises may be allowed by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade and the Federal Secretariat for Finance to export the necessary capital. A Decision of the Yugoslav Federal Executive Council of October 14, 1955 requires the Yugoslav authorities to continue to permit the remittance of inheritances to citizens of the United States, provided that the remittance is requested within three years from the date of distribution of the estate. 625 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA Changes during 1965 July 1. As a temporary measure a premium of 33% per cent was introduced on the settlement rate of Din 750 per US$1 for receipts from tourism and inward remittances. July 26. A new par value for the Yugoslav dinar of Din 1,250 per US$1 was established with the International Monetary Fund; the use .of the settlement rate of Din 750 per US$1 was discontinued. The temporary exchange premium of 33% per cent on receipts from tourism and inward remittances (see July 1) was abolished, and all foreign payments and receipts were to take place at rates based on the new par value. This action was accompanied by the elimination of all export subsidies. A new customs tar iff was introduced bringing about important reductions in duties and at the same time making certain duties more effectively and selectively protective when this was considered desirable; the average rate of duty on primary products was reduced from 12 per cent to 5 per cent, that on semifinished goods from 17 per cent to 9 per cent, that on investment goods from 43 per cent to 20 per cent, and that on consumer goods from 44 per cent to 21 per cent. The average over-all rate of import duty declined from 21 per cent to 10.5 per cent. August 1. The discount on certain sales of manufactured goods was reduced from 20 per cent to 10 per cent. August 11. The amount of Yugoslav banknotes which travelers could take into Yugoslavia was raised f rom Din 5,000 to Din 10,000, while the amount of Yugoslav banknotes which travelers could take out was raised f rom Din 1.500 to Din 5,000. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA 1 Exchange Rate System The currency of Zambia is the Zambian Pound. The Zambian pound is at par with the pound sterling, the official value of the Zambian pound being 2.48828 grams of fine gold, which corresponds to £Z 1 = US$2.80. The authorized banks base their rates for other cur- rencies on the current London market rates. On December 31, 1965, the rate for the U.S. dollar was US$2.815/8 buying, and US$2.78% sell- ing, per £Z 1. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Zambia under powers delegated to it by the Minister of Finance. Much of the author- ity for approving normal current payments is in turn delegated to the commercial and merchant banks. The control of trade is the responsi- bility of the Minister of Commerce and Industry, who also issues import and export licenses. Prescription of Currency Zambia is a member of the Sterling Area and maintains prescrip- tion of currency requirements similar to those of the United Kingdom. Settlements with residents of other countries in the Sterling Area may be made in Zambian pounds, in sterling, or in other Sterling Area currencies. Authorized payments, including payments for imports, by residents of Zambia to residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Rhodesia may be made in sterling or in Zambian pounds to the credit of an External Account, or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian pounds. Payments f rom countries outside the Sterling Area except Rhodesia may be received in sterling or in Zambian pounds f rom an External Account, or in any currency freely exchangeable for sterling. Special regulations apply to settlements with Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Zambian pounds held by residents of other parts of the Sterling Area are designated Scheduled Area Accounts. These accounts may be credited with the proceeds f rom sales of any foreign currency except Rhodesian pounds, with authorized payments by resi- dents, and with transfers f rom other Scheduled Area Accounts. Bal- 1 Zambia became a member of the International Monetary Fund on Sep- tember 23,1965. 627 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA ances on these accounts may be converted freely into other Sterling Area currencies, may be used to pay residents of Zambia, or may be transferred to other Scheduled Area Accounts. Accounts in Zambian pounds held with authorized banks by resi- dents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Rhodesia are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with authorized payments from residents of the Sterling Area, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any foreign currency except Rhodesian pounds by nonresidents to authorized banks. They may be debited for payments to residents of the Sterling Area, for transfers to other External Accounts or to Scheduled Area Accounts, and for purchases of any foreign currency other than Rhodesian pounds f rom authorized banks. Blocked Accounts in Zambian pounds held with authorized banks by residents of any country other than Zambia are credited with non- transferable capital sums in Zambian currency which have accrued to nonresidents. All debits and credits to such accounts require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. Normally, approval is given for the investment of balances on blocked accounts in Zambian securities, provided that these are held in Zambia to the order of an authorized dealer. The interest on blocked account balances is freely transferable to the account holder's country of residence. Imports and Import Payments Imports from any source of a few items listed in an open general license do not require individual licenses. These goods are mainly certain oil products, coke, exposed cinematographic film, personal and household effects, samples, diplomatic shipments, and goods imported by post or air freight. All other goods require an individual import license, regardless of the country of origin. Foreign exchange or permission to credit a nonresident account in accordance with the prescription of currency regulations is authorized automatically for all permitted imports, subject to the presentation of the relevant documents showing that the goods have either been received in or consigned to Zambia. Unless prior permission is other- wise obtained, all imports must be paid for within six months of the date of importation. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain limits, for other purposes, such as travel, is provided by the 628 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA commercial banks without prior reference to the exchange control. Special, reduced allocations apply to payments for invisibles to Rhodesia. For other countries, exchange is granted as follows. The basic exchange allowance for travel is £Z 10 a day for an adult, with a maximum of £Z 450 each calendar year, and £Z 5 a day for each child under 12 years of age, with a maximum of £Z 225 each calendar year. The allowance is cumulative for a period of not more than three years. Exchange is provided, subject to certain limits, for other purposes, such as education, medical treatment, and business travel. Applications for amounts exceeding the limits are granted by the exchange control authorities if they are satisfied that the exchange is needed for genuine current payments. Foreign nationals employed in Zambia under contract are permitted to remit up to two thirds of their earnings to Sterling Area coun t r ies ;2 applications for remittances to other countries are considered on their merits. To facilitate small payments, individuals are freely permitted to remit abroad up to £Z 10 a month for purposes normally approved by the exchange control authorities. Travelers may not take out more than £Z 10 in Zambian currency notes and the equivalent of £Z 10 in foreign currency notes. Exports and Export Proceeds Almost all goods require an export license. Certain commodities are subject to licensing mainly to ensure domestic supplies of needed goods and of certain strategic materials.3 For most goods, however, export licenses are issued freely. Export proceeds in foreign currency appropriate to the country of destination must be offered for sale to an authorized bank within six months of the date of shipment. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any currency must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. There is no limitation on the amount of foreign currency notes that may be imported by travelers, but not more than £Z 10 in Zambian currency notes may be imported. The import of old Southern Rhodesian or Bank of Rhodesia and Nyasaland currency notes is prohibited. 2 From February 10, 1966, persons recruited outside Zambia on a contract basis of not more than five years could remit only one half of their earnings, and those recruited in Zambia only one third. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted. Outward transfers of capital, including those to other parts of the Sterling Area, are controlled, but nonresidents are normally permitted to repatriate their investments when they have satisfied the authorities that the original investment was made with funds brought into the country from sources outside Zambia. In general, residents are not permitted to transfer capital abroad and, with certain exceptions, are required to o f fer for sale to an authorized bank any foreign exchange which accrues to them. As a special measure, however, residents may purchase Zambian securities quoted on recognized stock exchanges in the Sterling Area, provided that the securities so acquired are registered in the names of specified nominees and that in the event of the subsequent disposal of these securities the sales proceeds are repatriated. All income earned from these investments must be repatriated. Emigrants are granted exchange as follows: (1) Persons 50 years of age and over are allowed £Z 8,000 on departure, and subsequent annual transfers of £Z 5,000. (2) Married persons under 50 are allowed £Z 4,000 on departure, together with £Z 250 for each child, up to a maximum of £Z 5,000 for a fam i ly unit. Thereafter, annual transfers of £Z 3,000 together with £Z 250 for each child up to a maximum of £Z 4,000 for a family unit are permitted. (3) Unmarried persons under 50 are allowed £Z 2,000 on departure, and subsequent annual transfers of £Z 1,500. Changes during 1965 February 12.
